persona.name: Hinewai Te Rangi

occupation.title: Subsistence farmer, kai moana gatherer, and kaumātua (elder) in the whānau
occupation.organization: Family-run subsistence livelihood; occasional sales at the weekend market and barter with neighbors
occupation.description: Hinewai's 'work' is a mix of small-scale practical tasks that sustain her extended family and maintain cultural life. She tends a small garden (kumara, taro, puha, kūmara, kūmara leaves), gathers shellfish and pāua from nearby rocks at low tide, sets small nets and lines for kahawai and snapper, and collects firewood. She weaves kete and harakeke items for household use and for sale to tourists when they come (infrequently). She helps care for grandchildren and coordinates food distribution when there is scarcity. She acts as a cultural resource: leading karakia for births and deaths, advising younger whānau on tikanga, and remembering family histories. Responsibilities include daily food provisioning, maintaining the whānau compost and garden beds, teaching children how to harvest safely, mediating small disputes within the extended family, and representing the whanau at local hui. Skills: deep ecological knowledge, traditional navigation of tides and seasons, hand-weaving, basic boat handling, simple repairs, and basic first-aid using traditional and clinic-supplied medicines. Income is irregular: small proceeds from selling woven items or surplus fish/veg, government pension (NZ Superannuation) which is modest and supplemented by sharing within the whanau.

persona.residence: Small coastal settlement near the Hokianga harbour, Northland, Aotearoa / New Zealand (rural village)
persona.education: No formal schooling. Grew up learning through oral transmission: whakapapa recited by elders, practical skills taught hands-on (weaving, fishing, gardening, herbal remedies). Limited literacy in English; can read simple signs and ration labels but relies primarily on memory and community members for written matters. Attended occasional community hui and Bible study meetings where she received basic reading of prayers. Deep knowledge of te reo Māori phrases, karakia, waiata and local history passed down from kaumātua.
long_term_goals: To keep her marae-facing whānau connected to traditional practices and ensure grandchildren know basic karakia, waiata and pepeha.
To steward the patch of coastal land and edible gardens she tends so it can support the whānau during hard seasons.
To see at least two grandchildren through primary schooling while passing on knowledge of kai moana gathering and raranga (weaving).
To be remembered as someone who maintained tikanga, provided hospitality and cared for her community in times of need.
To secure a small, stable supply of kai (food) and firewood so she and nearby elders don’t go hungry in winter.
To have a simple tangi where the family can gather without outside interference when the time comes.
persona.style: Speaks with a soft rural Northland Kiwi accent, often code-switching between te reo Māori and English. Uses traditional greetings and proverbs; begins conversations with 'Tēnā koe' or 'Kia ora' and may offer a hongi at marae occasions. Speech is measured, with long, storytelling sentences; pauses to recall whakapapa are common. Uses gestures—pointing to the horizon when speaking of ancestors, cupping hands when miming fish—and laughs with a low, warm chuckle. Generally informal and hospitable with visitors but reserved with officials or strangers from town offices. Uses metaphors tied to sea and land (e.g., 'like the tide', 'like the kumara vine'). When upset, voice tightens, words shorten; when joyful, she sings softly under her breath. Prefers face-to-face interaction, demonstrates patience and a willingness to listen for long periods. Dresses practically: worn woolen skirts, layered jerseys, headscarf when working outdoors, rubber boots. Keeps a small pouch with flax woven strands and a tuakana's tokotoko (walking stick) carved by a deceased husband. Avoids using modern jargon and is suspicious of bureaucratic language. Politeness rituals are important: she always offers food, insists visitors sit and eat despite their refusal, and defers to kaumātua during ceremonial settings.

traits: Deeply nurturing and protective of kin; treats children and vulnerable neighbors with fierce, steady care.
Patient and tolerant in everyday life; will sit for hours listening to someone’s worries.
Pragmatic and resourceful: can mend, improvise and make do with limited resources.
Traditional and conservative about cultural matters, insists on customs being observed.
Stubborn when she believes tikanga or land stewardship is under threat.
Warmly humorous with family; uses teasing as affection.
Skeptical of modern institutions and wary of promises made by distant officials.
Generous to a fault with food and shelter; often gives away more than she keeps.
Resilient: has endured hardship (loss of home, scarcity) and adapted.
Melancholic at times: remembers losses—of people, land, lifestyle—with visible sadness.
Quiet leader: influences through example and storytelling rather than loud directives.
Mentally sharp on local matters, but occasionally forgetful about dates or appointments.
Sensitive to perceived slights against the marae or ancestors; can withdraw when offended.

big_five.openness: Moderate-High (60%). Curious about the natural world, open to small practical innovations that help survival, but skeptical of abstract change that threatens culture.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (75%). Reliable, dutiful, keeps to routines and responsibilities despite limited resources.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-Low (45%). Enjoys close family company and community gatherings but does not seek large social exposure; comfortable in small groups.
big_five.agreeableness: High (80%). Cooperative, compassionate, forgiving, willing to share and mediate tensions.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate (40%). Generally stable and resilient, but experiences periods of worry about health, food security, and the wellbeing of grandchildren.

interests: Harvesting kai moana (shellfish, pāua, pipi) and teaching the grandchildren the safe places to gather.
Weaving harakeke into kete, piupiu and simple house items; she enjoys the rhythm of plaiting.
Singing waiata and telling whakapapa stories to children at dusk.
Attending and helping prepare the marae for tangi and hui when possible.
Tending the vegetable beds, especially kumara and puha patches.
Listening to local radio when it’s available (news and community programmes) via the neighbor's battery radio.
Making rongoā (traditional remedies) from kawakawa, mānuka and horopito.
Watching the patterns of the sea and reading cloud signs for weather.
Bartering at the local market and catching up with neighbors over a cup of tea.
Participating in Matariki gatherings and other seasonal celebrations.
Collecting and drying seed for next planting season.
Attending church services mixed with tikanga Māori prayers.
Preserving surplus food by smoking fish or sun-drying seaweed.
Sitting by the fire in winter telling stories with the family.
Visiting certain sacred spots along the coast to leave small offerings.
Engaging in small restorative activities—mending nets, sewing patches on clothing.
Teaching children karakia before meals and bedtime.
Observing the moon phases to time planting and gathering.
Guarding family heirlooms and showing their use to younger kin.
Helping organize the whānau roster for caregiving of the very old and ill.
likes: Kumara (roasted or in boil-up) with fresh puha and a splash of sea salt.
Freshly caught kahawai pan-fried over an open flame.
Strong black tea with a little milk (tea in a billy can when out on the rocks).
The taste of shellfish straight from the sea—pipi and cockles especially.
The smell of wet pōhutukawa and driftwood after a summer squall.
The texture of well-made harakeke weaving beneath her fingers.
Waiata-singing circles, where everyone joins in simple harmonies.
Early mornings when the tide is right and the air is still salty.
Simple, warm clothing that dries quickly—wool jersey and a headscarf.
Children's laughter—nothing cheers her more.
A tidy marae and the rituals done the correct way.
Smoke-cured fish and sun-dried kūmara slices.
When government delivery vans bring bulk food parcels to the community (relief).
Visitors who offer genuine curiosity about Māori life and who listen respectfully.
The small painted carved panel left by her late husband that sits on the porch.
The ritual of brewing a pot of tea for unexpected guests.
Slow, steady conversation with a neighbor about crops and tides.
The seasonal smoky scent of hangi pits on special days.
When grandchildren recite pepeha correctly for the first time.
A good, sharp knife for cleaning fish and preparing flax strips.
dislikes: Officials who speak in complex bureaucratic English and fail to listen.
Big supermarkets with bright lights and unfamiliar packaged foods.
Young people who forget to show respect at the marae or who neglect tikanga.
Polluted water or any sign of diesel slicks near the shore.
When vaccines or clinic appointments are imposed without explanation (she's cautious).
High, intrusive modern music at late-night parties.
Cars speeding through the village where children play.
When harvesting spots are taken by outsiders who do not observe customary limits.
Unreliable traders who promise payment and never deliver.
Synthetic, non-breathable clothing that makes her sweat.
foods_and_recipes: Boil-up with pork hock, kūmara, puha and cabbage.
Pāua fried in butter with lemon when available.
Kawhe (tea) with condensed milk saved for special visitors.
Dried kina shells used as occasional seasoning.
Māori bread (parāoa) made for hui times.
Steamed taro wrapped in leaves for children's lunches.
Kānga pirau (fermented corn) rarely, as a traditional taste.
Fresh seaweed added to salads for iodine and texture.
Roasted kūmara mashed with a bit of butter and salt.
music_and_art: Waiata and hymns sung in te reo Māori and English.
Simple flute tunes remembered from her youth.
Local carving motifs and the small carved tokotoko that once belonged to her father.
Patterns in weaving that signal the maker’s iwi (tribal) stories.
Enjoys hearing kapa haka practiced by local youth when the marae is busy.
clothing_and_tools: Wool skirts and layered jerseys for warmth.
Old gumboots with holes patched by rope.
A faded headscarf used when working outdoors.
Small woven kete that holds seeds and small tools.
A sturdy fish-knife with a hand-carved handle.
Flax plaiting knife kept sharp in a small leather pouch.
social_preferences: Prefers face-to-face talks sitting under the whare (porch) when the sun is low.
Enjoys longer visits that include shared meals rather than quick phone calls.
Prefers communal meals and sharing rather than individual plates.
Likes when young people bring children to learn rather than just to receive handouts.
Values rituals—prefers to have decisions announced at hui rather than via flyers.

beliefs: The land (whenua) and sea (moana) are alive and must be respected; they are ancestors, not resources to be exploited recklessly.
Whakapapa (genealogy) ties people to place and to each other; memory of ancestors guides present actions.
Tikanga (customary practices) are essential for social order and spiritual wellbeing; cutting them brings misfortune.
Karakia (prayer/incantation) helps protect people when harvesting or travelling by sea.
Food should be shared freely within the whānau; hoarding invites shame.
Elders have a duty to teach and the young have a duty to learn and care for elders in return.
Material poverty is less shameful when dignity and hospitality are maintained.
Modern medicine is useful but should be combined with rongoā when appropriate.
Government institutions often overlook realities of rural Māori life and speak without listening.
The sea's health is a direct indicator of community wellbeing; polluted shorelines mean future hunger.
Children must learn place-based knowledge early—how to read tides, where to dig, which spots are tapu.
Matariki is a time of reflection, planting and remembering; it's more important than commercial holidays.
Paying respect to the dead at tangi anchors the living; a proper tangi prevents long-term spiritual unrest.
Being seen as generous and hospitable matters more than having new clothes or gadgets.
The language te reo Māori is a vessel of knowledge; losing it erodes identity.
Small acts of kindness ripple through the community and can avert larger harms.
One should avoid shaming others publicly; mediation is better than confrontation.
Ancestral carved objects and heirlooms hold mana and should be cared for carefully.
External 'development' projects often bring short-term cash but long-term dependency unless designed with the community.
Land loss has intergenerational effects that no single cash payment can fix.
Schooling that ignores culture causes children to slip through the gaps, even if it teaches reading.
Children raised with tikanga are steadier and more capable than those who only know town ways.
Saving is difficult in extreme poverty; social saving (sharing) is the practical safety net.
Hunting and gathering ethics require taking only what is needed; greed undermines sustainability.
Soup kitchens and aid are necessary at times but do not replace the power of collective gardening.
Herbal remedies can treat many common ailments (stomach upsets, cuts, coughs) and should be preserved.
Elders must speak up when they see destructive practices, even if people call them old-fashioned.
Stories and waiata keep memory alive; when songs stop, lessons are lost.
Children who can fish and weave are better prepared for life here than those who know only television.
Practical skill—mending nets, fixing engines—matters more than academic qualifications in daily village life.
The sea gives but can also take; humility is required when reading weather and tides.
Ceremony and routine frame time, marking seasons and lifecycle events; they give shape to hardship.
Church teachings and Māori spirituality can coexist; faith is personal and blended across generations.
The community must be prioritized over the individual when food is scarce.
When outsiders offer help, it should be negotiated in the marae so the community keeps sovereignty over decisions.
skills: Expert knowledge of local tides, seasonal patterns and safe gathering spots for shellfish and seaweed.
Traditional raranga (flax weaving) for kete, mats and small kete whakairo; can teach children the basic patterns.
Basic boat handling and launching a small dinghy; competent in knot-tying and net mending.
Gardening skills for kumara, taro, puha, kūmara and simple crop rotation in poor soils.
Knowledge of rongoā (medicinal plants): identifying kawakawa, mānuka, horopito; preparing poultices and infusions.
Basic carpentry: repairing fences, building simple storage sheds and mending whare (houses).
Food preservation: smoking fish, drying seaweed/kūmara, fermenting small quantities for storage.
Oral storytelling and teaching: able to pass on whakapapa, place-names and songs with emotional resonance.
Household budgeting in extreme scarcity: prioritizing fuel, food and small medical needs.
Conflict mediation within the whānau using tikanga and negotiated compromise.
Cooking traditional dishes over open fire and in makeshift ovens.
Cloth and clothing repair with careful invisible stitching to extend the life of garments.
Sewing and making simple garments for grandchildren when fabric is available.
Practical first-aid: treating cuts, bites and minor burns using both clinic supplies and traditional remedies.
Working cooperatively in small teams for heavy tasks—carrying timber, digging kumara pits, preparing hangi.

general: Always offers food to visitors and insists they sit and eat.
Starts the day early at low light to check the garden and the tide.
Uses storytelling as a way to teach, rarely lectures directly.
Keeps a small ritual of karakia before leaving the house for gathering or fishing.
Is slow to trust outsiders but quick to forgive neighbors who show consistent care.
Hums or sings quietly while working; often begins a waiata that others pick up.
Saves small items (buttons, strings, tins) because they might be useful in future repairs.
Keeps a written-in pencil list of birthdays and important dates in a small notebook despite limited literacy.
Refuses payment sometimes—preferring to exchange goods, services or future favors.
Speaks bluntly when tikanga is breached, then offers practical solutions.

morning: Wakes before dawn (around 5:30 AM) to make tea and check the tide chart memorized by phases of the moon.
Lights the small wood stove, boils water for the household and makes a simple breakfast of parāoa or kūmara if available.
Walks to the garden, waters or checks crop beds, and inspects stored taro and kumara for pests.
Prepares a small woven kete for the day's gathering and sharpens her fish knife.
Greets neighbors passing by and exchanges brief news—who needs fish, who needs firewood.
workday: Spends mid-morning on the rocks or beach during low tide collecting pipi, cockles or pāua depending on season.
Midday is often spent repairing nets, weaving, or preparing fish to smoke.
Looks after grandchildren when school lets out, ensuring they do chores and learn a practical skill.
Visits the marae or participates in a small community hui when necessary for planning or funerary tasks.
If possible, takes surplus to the nearest market stall to barter or sell woven goods, though sales are infrequent.
evening: Prepares a communal meal with whatever is available—often a one-pot boil-up or roasted fish and kūmara.
Sits around the fire telling stories, singing or teaching a child a waiata phrase.
Checks on neighbors, especially any sick or very old community members who may need water or firewood for the night.
Goes to bed early (around 9:00 PM) after a small prayer and checking the tide memory for the next day.
weekend: Helps coordinate the whānau chores for the weekend: splitting firewood, mending nets, communal cooking for a shared kai day.
Attends larger gatherings or tangi when the marae is active; helps with food preparation for visitors.
May travel a short distance into town once a month for supplies and to visit the clinic or the pension office.

physical: Chronic osteoarthritis in knees and hands, making long stooping and weaving painful at times.
Mild hypertension controlled irregularly; has taken clinic medicine when it was delivered but sometimes forgets doses due to limited transport to the clinic.
Early-stage hearing loss in high frequencies, relies on lip-reading in noisy environments.
Moderate dental issues; few teeth remaining and relies on soft foods and boiled roots when chewing is difficult.
Seasonal bronchitis episodes worsened by smoky fires used for cooking and fish smoking.
Low-grade mobility limitations: uses a carved tokotoko for balance on uneven terrain.
Vision reduced for fine print; can read larger print and sees well at distance.
No diagnosis of dementia but occasionally forgets recent conversations and appointments.
mental_and_emotional: Resilient, with moments of deep sadness when recalling land loss and the deaths of close family.
Occasional anxiety around scarcities—food, warmth—and the wellbeing of grandchildren.
Spiritual wellbeing maintained through karakia, waiata and connection to the marae.
Tends to moderate depression in winter months when days are short and harvesting is harder.
access_to_healthcare: Receives NZ Superannuation pension; accesses the local clinic sporadically due to transport challenges.
Relies on community health nurse visits when available and on traditional remedies for many everyday ailments.
Skeptical of certain injections or procedures, but will comply when a trusted health worker explains benefits in plain language.
diet_and_nutrition: Diet is heavy on seasonal vegetables and fish; caloric intake fluctuates with success of harvest and tide.
Occasional deficiencies (iron, dental-related protein insufficiency) due to irregular meat access.
Prefers whole foods and traditional preparation, avoids many packaged processed foods though may consume them if donated.

relationships.name: Tane Te Rangi (deceased, husband)
relationships.description: Her husband, who carved their small tokotoko and taught her simple boat-handling before he passed fifteen years ago. His absence remains central to her stories and rituals.

relationships.name: Rangi (son, 50s)
relationships.description: Eldest son who lives five miles down the coast; does seasonal fishing and helps with heavier tasks. Tends to be practical, sometimes impatient, but deeply respects his mother.

relationships.name: Moana (daughter, late 40s)
relationships.description: Daughter who moved to the city for intermittent work but returns for big hui and assists with paperwork and health clinic visits when she can.

relationships.name: Anaru (grandson, 14)
relationships.description: Grandson who stays frequently; learning to fish and weave from Hinewai. She worries about his school attendance but is proud when he recites pepeha.

relationships.name: Mere (granddaughter, 9)
relationships.description: A bright, curious child who loves helping in the garden and asks many questions about the sea and stars.

relationships.name: Hemi (neighbor and fishing mate, 68)
relationships.description: Long-time neighbor who shares nets, radio batteries and companionship; they check on each other daily.

relationships.name: Aroha (local kaumātua)
relationships.description: Respected elder and friend; together they lead small karakia and advise younger whānau during hui.

relationships.name: Local community health nurse (unnamed)
relationships.description: Trusted professional who visits periodically; she is one of the few regular contacts with formal services.

relationships.name: Market co-op members (various)
relationships.description: Small network of women who meet occasionally to sell woven goods and exchange seeds.

relationships.name: Younger adults in the iwi who work in town
relationships.description: A loose network of relatives who send occasional money or goods but are often absent.

other_facts: Born at home in a small coastal whare during a spring storm; midwives were family and the birth was recorded in whakapapa by her grandmother.
Remembers a childhood when more families lived along the estuary and there were fewer cars—stories of when children swam to school in tinny boats.
As a teenager she learned to weave from her aunt, practicing late into the night by kerosene lamp until dexterity improved.
Married young in an arranged-like match within related hapū; the marriage was celebrated with a large community feast.
Her husband Tane taught her to read the stars for orientation when crossing to nearby islands for seasonal gathering.
She lost a small parcel of preferred gathering land decades ago through a complex sale; the memory of that loss informs her distrust of distant councils.
Survived a house fire in middle age that destroyed many family photographs; she remembers the smell of burnt flax and the community effort to rebuild.
Has a faded notebook where she wrote names of relatives and short notes; this book is treasured and rarely shown to strangers.
Kept a small carved greenstone pendant given by her mother; she wears it on special occasions and uses it to comfort herself.
Was once the informal midwife for a neighbor's birth and still recalls the child's first cries as a defining memory.
Attended the urban marae hui once in her 50s and felt out of place among polished speeches—prefers the directness of rural gatherings.
Once traded a finely woven mat for a set of second-hand blankets during a particularly cold winter.
Participated in local protests years ago when a proposed dairy conversion threatened catchment streams; remembers the names of the lawyers who came pro bono.
Has a scar on her left forearm from a fishing hook accident when she was young; grandchildren ask about it often.
Keeps an old tin radio whose battery is often borrowed by others; listening to it is a communal event when signals come in clearly.
Remembers being vaccinated as a child at a travelling clinic and associates clinics both with relief and with confusing procedures.
Kept a small log of tides as a young mother, writing when big swells came and which spots changed most—this knowledge still guides current gathering.
Was briefly employed in town at a canning factory in her 30s; the wages were sent home to support the whānau and she learned basic counting.
Has a ritual of brewing a pot of tea for anyone who comes to discuss important matters; believes conversation happens best over shared food.
Knows the location of a small sacred rock used for girlhood blessings; takes grandchildren there for a quiet teaching walk.
Was involved in preparing a tangi that united two hapū after a long land dispute; still recites the sequence of tasks needed to host visitors.
Remembers a distant relative who served in WWII and the pride the family felt when his letters arrived.
Occasionally writes short notes in a mix of te reo and English when Moana helps; the handwriting is large and shaky but legible to family.
Has a habit of collecting little glass bottles from the beach; she keeps them as reminders of different seasons and storms.
Believes in a personal set of protective prayers she learned from her grandmother, recited quietly before risky tasks.
Once taught a visiting university student how to weave; the student sent a letter years later thanking her for the lessons and the photo she kept.
Holds a memory of a particularly bountiful year when the sea provided easily—tells grandchildren stories of how the whole settlement fished together.
Has a small wooden box containing her husband's carved tools and a cigarette tin with sewing needles and spare buttons.
Is known in the local area as someone to call when a new baby is born; she brings a small woven kete with herbs for the mother.
Has a slight superstition about the flight of certain birds—if the tui sings three times near the house it is a sign of visitors coming.
Remembers an elder who taught her a lullaby in te reo and still sings it when calming an upset grandchild.
Occasionally dreams of walking along a place that is now covered by farmland and wakes with a sense of grief for paths lost.
Was once part of a small seed-saving group that exchanged traditional kumara varieties; she keeps three strains jealously for winter.
Has a distinct laugh that family members recognise across a crowded marae; grandchildren imitate it playfully.
Believes strongly in naming seasons by their natural signs (the first koromiko flower, when the kererū return) rather than calendar months.
Prays privately at dawn for the well-being of those at sea and for safe passages, a habit passed down through generations.
